text.p: The following are the main stories from Friday morning's Austrian newspapers:
DER STANDARD

- Opposition parties in parliament will stop all work in the committees in order to force the government coalition to launch an investigation into the affair around the release of the alleged Iranian murderers of three Kurdish leaders in 1989. Social Democrat and Conservative chief whips Peter Kostelka and Andreas Khol call it a refusal of democracy and a breach of the constitution.
- Die Erste savings bank plans a capital increase in 1998 after having merged with GiroCredit.
- Insurance holding BARC plans to sell its products within the European Union.
- Austria's current account deficit widened to eight billion schillings in the first quarter of 1997 as exports and tourist sales fell.
- Lenzing will scrap its 1996 dividend due to losses.
- Steelmaker Boehler-Uddeholm is thinking about investing 100 million schillings into a new production facility in the province of Styria.

- The first working groups have started talks on the merging of Bank Austria and Creditanstalt's businesses. Bank Austria took over the government's stake in Creditanstalt at the beginnig of the year.
DIE PRESSE

- Boehler-Uddeholm's first quarter pre-tax profits fell to 166 million schillings from 443 million the year before. But the company remains optimistic However expectations are positive as orders are on the rise.
- Insurer BARC plans to pass on any synergy effects to its customers even before the savings are made.
- Mautner Markhof will sell its drinks unit to Germany's Eckes' Austrian unit Stock&Stroh as the company reported pre-tax losses of 135 million schillings.
- Bank Austria plans to increase its capital by 3.6 billion schillings in order to pay for the swapping of Creditanstalt shares.
- Private investors and strategic partners should pay for Die Erste savings bank's planned capital increase.
KURIER
- Foreign Minister Wolfgang Schuessel says labour interests, ecology and social security will become part of the European Union's agreement.
- Austria's food producers had to further reduce production and cut jobs in 1996 while pressure by retailers grew.
SALZBURGER NACHRICHTEN
- Post & Telekom Austria wants a blocking minority in postal savings bank PSK which is due to be privatised.
